This movie is atrocious by all outside metrics - It's slow moving, it's poorly edited, it's painfully contrived, it's noticeably cheap looking andit's kind of fun to watch. Okay, maybe it's a stretch to say that the fifth installment of this morose ode to fang kink is fun to watch. It's clear from the generous amounts of recaps, flash backs and the, oh so overused callbacks the Underworld series (2003-Present) has all but run out of steam. Yet what remains serviceable about this film, the action sequences, the reductive sexuality, the Supernatural (2005-Present) meets Game of Thrones (2011-Present) intrigue, is precisely what the fans want.Underworld: Blood Wars begins with a sloppily edited, voice over recap about our long suffering protagonist's journey from scrappy vampire warrior to bloodsucker pariah, to mother of "the chosen one." We then see Selene (Beckinsale) take on a pack of fanatic werewolves whose new leader Marius (Menzies) has a vested interest in Selene's daughter's blood. Problem is Selene doesn't know where her daughter is – the lycans, don't know where her daughter is – the vampire clan shoehorned into this movie, also don't know where her daughter is! Seriously has no one called for an Amber Alert at this point? Selene is then wrapped up into the palace intrigue of a prestigious vampire coven, led by Semira (Pulver) whose nefarious plans are as webbed and needlessly contrived as her outfits. Watching this film spill its yarn was like enduring the uncomfortable S&M fantasies of a zealous Dungeons and Dragons DM. There's half-thought-out drivel about pure blood vampire lines, Selene somehow harnessing the power to create mirages, the war between vampires and lycans which is always a fixture – then there are the elves. The movie explains they're a secluded coven of vampires but no, they're f***ing elves! There's a lot of ridiculousness in this film is my point and not a single scene goes on without elongated monologues spouting exposition. Yet while the machinery of Blood Wars loudly chugs along, a recalibration is happening. In the mix are series holdovers David (T. James) and lead vampire daddy Thomas (Dance), whose character arcs clunkily reach some kind of resolution. Our villain Marius likewise borrows up-in-the-air elements from earlier installments and clumsily curb stomps them so they'll (hopefully) never be mentioned again. Add to all this the fact that you never actually find out what happened to the daughter and it feels to me that the series is slicing on through and then asking for a mulligan.It's all very obvious and at times too cringe-worthy to bear, but with so many scenes littered in form-fitting leather, it's now possible to conclude this series finally knows what its doing. I mean come on, the film goes so far as to introduce the baby-faced Alexia (Head) and the chiseled Vargas (B. James); two characters whose main jobs are to be sexual props for other characters. From the fan's perspective, this IP essentially amounts to nothing more than elaborate Gothic role-play, faux elegant depictions of bloodletting, cool ninja warrior acrobatics and a female protagonist who gets off on being hurt. I'm not saying I approve but having our hero rip out a werewolf's spine while in a literal cage is arguably better than the Romeo and Juliet bulls**t we got in the first one.

Review title: Belongs to the so bad it's good camp. We're loving it!
Review_body: While Sony's blockbuster slate has been pretty sluggish in the box office, their horror label Screen Gems has enjoyed better success from low-budgeted thrillers like Don't Breathe and two popular franchises, Resident Evil and Underworld -the former releasing its sixth and final chapter next January and Kate Beckinsale reprising her role as death dealer Selene for the fifth time in the latter.Picking up after the events of Underworld: Awakening which sees the birth of Selene's hybrid daughter, Eve. Underworld: Blood Wars opens with Selene being haunted by her own kind and Lycans as both sides are out to seek the blood of Eve. The Vampires are losing the war as the Lycans clan led by Marius (Tobias Menzies from Game of Thrones) is getting stronger by the day. On the pretext of seeking assistance from Selene, the scheming Semira (Lara Pulver) approaches her help to train a new batch of death dealers. Unbeknownst to her, an internal rife is brewing and Selene's only ally happens to be David (Theo James from Divergent), the son of Vampire Elder, Thomas (Charles Dance from Games of Thrones yet again).German-born cinematographer (White House Down) and TV director (Outlander, Criminal Minds) Anna Foerster takes over the directing duties for this instalment. It is frankly a thankless task to take over a franchise that hardly wins over the critics over the years but Foerster does a commendable job balancing the story and insane action sets. For the relatively brief running time, Foerster and her screenwriters Cory Goodman (The Last Witch Hunter) and Kyle Ward (Machete Kills) provides the various lead characters enough exposition and screen time for audiences to connect the dots at least for the first 45 minutes.Besides being a family member to Selene, David is also on a journey to find out his true birth heritage that concerns his mysterious mother who left him after childbirth. The ambitious Semira and her aide cum lover Varga (Bradley James) plots to conquer the Vampire faction and Selene is constantly battling her own inner demons. On the Lycan side, the powerful Lycan leader Marius has a dark secret of his own. We are even introduced to the mysterious vampires residing in the cold Nordic coven. Honestly, you can't really blame the franchise for not trying to expand the Vampire mythos which in actual fact it actually does.For Underworld fans who are hungry for more blood and gore, Underworld: Blood Wars has no lack of it. The last 45 minutes is an action- packed bloodletting orgy of sorts. Heads are sliced, countless shots are fired and it even boasts a WTF moment when two leads start firing at each other at close range. It's great to see some slick action choreography being displayed particularly the scene where Selene battles the transformed Marius on top of a frozen seabed.Obviously because of time constraint and budget, CGI is favored over animatronic effects for the Lycans, which accounts for the weakest aspect of all. There is decent cinematography, excellent location shoot in Prague and rather impressive set designs. Best of all, Kate Beckinsale remains the draw in her ass-tight spandex. She seems not have aged a day since she first played Selene in the original 2004's Underworld, such that one wonders if she is really a death dealer in reality. For a dumb action fantasy, Underworld: Blood Wars certainly entertains, and obviously the franchise is very much opened to further developments.

Review title: "Underworld: Blood Wars"- A mildly entertaining but ultimately mediocre installment in the long-running franchise. A solid script is let down by a weirdly uneven execution.
Review_body: While never quite becoming a massive mainstream success, the long running and generally popular cult-franchise "Underworld" has for the most part been a great deal of fun to follow for the past decade-and-a-half. With its trademark gothic visuals and a flare for top-notch action, the ongoing saga about the battle between vampires and werewolves has remained consistently entertaining and engaging, even as it's gotten progressively sillier with each new installment.Unfortunately, after the films reached a surprisingly pleasing crescendo in quality with the third installment "Rise of the Lycans", there was a noticeable dip in quality with the follow-up, "Awakening." It began to lose sight of why audiences fell in love with the series in the first place. And that downward trend does sadly continue in the newest chapter- "Underworld: Blood Wars." While by no means a terrible film, the fundamental issue with "Blood Wars" falls on one key issue- guidance. It boasts a pretty good story and some solid writing... but is drastically let down by a weirdly awkward and frankly clunky execution.Kate Beckinsale returns as former Death Dealer Selene, now on the run with her friend and ally David, played again by Theo James. After being betrayed by power-hungry vampire heiress Semira (Lara Pulver), Selene and David are forced to take refuge with a clan of Nordic Vampires hiding out in the arctic. Here, they will come across revelations that could hold the key to turning the tide of the war between vampires and werewolves. But it may not be enough, as both species have become woefully misguided and bloodthirsty from centuries of pointless war, and been driven to the point of near extinction...First things first, as always the cast is pretty darned solid. Beckinsale is as fiery and fierce as ever in her iconic role as the vampire assassin Selene, and I actually really enjoyed Theo James and how he handled the character of David this time around. Charles Dance brings a sense of class and gravitas in his returning role of Thomas, and we get a pretty good turn from Tobias Menzies as a Lycan lord named Marius. Menzies, best known for his roles in series like "Game of Thrones" and "The Crown," does well with the part and gives it a nice sense of menace, even if he's never really the main focus. The same cannot be said for Lara Pulver, however, who comes across as, well... a bit silly as the vampire villainess Semira. She plays the role as a spoiled brat, and it feels contrived and at odds with the other performances.Writing duties are handled by series newcomers Cory Goodman and Kyle Ward, and I actually for the most part felt that they were a good fit. Their combined credits include a slew of odd and unusual films, and it benefits the story, which takes many intriguing twists and turns I might not have expected otherwise. Particularly fascinating is the addition of the Nordic vampire tribe, which have their own unique methodology and temperament... almost feeling more akin to spiritual monks than traditional blood-suckers. It gave the franchise a fresh new perspective that hearkened back to the originality of prior films, and was very much needed after the tonal inconsistencies of the previous installment.Unfortunately, the film falls apart all too often due to the mixed efforts of director Anna Foerster, in her feature-film debut. Foerster, whom has worked on a number of high profile films in the past as a cinematographer and effects artist, sadly isn't able to muster much excitement nor style with her first major foray into filmmaking. Her sense of scope and composition is limited and stilted, and the sense of pacing she constructs is so manic as to be distracting. The film moves far too fast for its own good, and lacks a clear focus on narrative and character. Foerster knows how to block a scene technically... but not how to convey emotion or story within that scene. It's almost heartbreaking, because she doesn't slow down enough at all to allow us to take in the sights, the feelings, etc. She's just too pre-occupied on hitting beats and checkmarks. And it tanks almost every major sequence. With the exception of the admittedly well-staged action and a very fun climax, it's just woefully not well made.It's frankly mind-boggling how the poor pacing and construction almost completely ruins what could have otherwise been a pretty decent entry in the series. And it just goes to show you how invaluable series co-creator Len Wiseman was to the success of those early installments."Underworld: Blood Wars" is a frustrating film. It has so much potential, but squanders much of it with its uneven and shoddy execution. And it only lessened my excitement for potential future films. My advice? Bring back Beckinsale and the series creators Wiseman and Danny McBride for one last film... hopefully one that will redeem the series after the weaknesses brought about by the one-two punch of "Awakening" and "Blood Wars." Go out with a bang, guys. Otherwise, "Underworld" might very well be finished. I'm giving "Blood Wars" a middle of the road 5 out of 10. It's just creative and entertaining enough to be worth a watch for series fans. But it's thus far the weakest of the bunch.

Review title: Decent dance of wit and blade, if not slightly tainted
Review_body: In the first act alone Blood Wars drops a more diverse cast and flexible subplots than other Underworld titles. The clashing politic is handled mostly well and it's always a boon to have more persistently Gothic characters. However, the production feels fragmented, often speeds up in certain area in expense of these colorful personalities while also hashing out the same outdated slow motion barrage from last decade.Unlike previous installments which utilized one simple plot line, Blood Wars tries to introduce several ideals with the Lycan and vampires, even discord among each group while Selene is once again caught in the cross fire. The setup offers more in term of content and the characters, while they may be a tad overzealous, work well in intended effect.There's unfortunately not much range on the characters themselves. Kate Beckinsale is her usual brooding self, down to the monologue delivery, although the jumpsuit look agelessly suits her. Theo James as David serves as the male protagonist, he's sadly still walking in Michael's shadow who died a few episodes ago.Lara Pulver plays as Semira, a rather Eva Green or Lena Headey type of evil queen. She and Charles Dance, the elder vampire, gives off Game of Thrones aura at least for at a portion of the movie. With more cast, some motivations are unfortunately vague, Tobias Menzies as Marius has the potential to rise above the horde but ultimately he doesn't feel intimidating or intelligent enough for an arch-nemesis.The action follows almost the exact formula Underworld used, much like the on-screen vampire counterpart who stays unchanged. Expect plenty of slow motion or jarring shots, although there are a few scenes that look crisp though they only occur briefly. It would have benefited a lot from better choreography since there's a limit on how captivating someone turns into a CGI werewolf can be.There are admittedly deeper aspects at play here, Blood Wars attempts to further the lore and introduce more eccentric characters. Yet with the power of choppy editing these people are given strange motives while unceremoniously thrown in and out from one scene to another. In the end of the night, it's still not that bad of return for Selene and her pack.

Review title: Can these movies get any dumber?
Review_body: At this point, I'm just exhausted and bored with the Underworld franchise. It never feels like they are progressing the story, but they remain planted in the same war between vampire and lycan that has been going on for 4 films already. Underworld: Blood Wars isn't even a strong follow-up chapter, because they write out one of the major characters from the previous film (Selene's daughter) and start to diminish her importance by making Selene just as valuable. The action continues to be bland and dull, and this is the first time in one of these films that I openly laughed out loud during a battle. It was already dumb, but now it's like they're trying to make the use of guns in a war between the undead downright goofy. In the climax of the film there's a face-off between two major characters where they literally shake off dozens of bullets before screaming in each other's faces, and I lost it. I cannot fathom why the characters in these movies continue to arm themselves with ordinary bullets when they keep introducing ammunition that can kill or cripple a vampire or lycan in one shot.Of course, just like the stupidity with the guns, the powers of the creatures also seem inconsistent. I get so annoyed with the way they are knocked down and thrown around by an enemy in one scene, and then they seem to tear through them with the greatest of ease in the next. That's the kind of thing that is indicative of the bad writing that has run throughout the Underworld series, and has pushed my ability to tolerate it too far by the time I landed on Blood Wars. In this movie they also fall into the trap of writing for the sake of convenience. You always know there's something wrong with a script when you introduce a new concept to the mythos of the franchise, and then a mere 10 minutes later the main character is utilizing that information. It's just lazy, and takes me out of the film every time. I also hated how they continued to expand the "blood memory" thing to the extreme here. Now, if even a drop of someone's blood hits a vampire's lip, they get flashes of that person's memory. Heck, you can even relive your own past with a bite to themselves. Underworld: Blood Wars has a couple scenes that I liked because they had potential, but otherwise it was a total bust.

My first experience of film from 2017 happens to be the latest installment in a series that I am extremely mixed on. I love the original Underworld. I loved the universe created and thought it was a well crafted action film with a good balance of both style and substance. Unfortunately, none of the sequels were close in quality to the original and a few of the films kind of just faded into the background. I wasn't overly excited for Blood Wars but all I really wanted was a decent film that is at least better than some of the sequels.The film starts off explaining some of the key events of the previous in the franchise (which I really needed as a refresher). It takes a while for the film to really get going. We see a few new characters, all with their own motivations. You really wonder who is doing what and it takes time to really frame the story. I felt uninterested through the first act. The film does get better once we see more of Tobias Menzies' villainous character. I think with so many films in the franchise its easy to forget characters and all about the vampire/werewolf hybrids and what the Lycans are really after.Kate Beckinsale is gorgeous as always in the film. Her Selene character always kicks ass and looks incredibly sexy in a black leather suit. I also dug remodeling her character with the blondish locks in her hair. The dark blue hue of the film is back once again but its cool because the film looks really stylish and the Gothic feel of the Underworld universe is ever present. There's more than enough action and bloody violence to keep the moviegoer entertained. Its important to remember that these films are gearing more towards popcorn entertainment than something that can be take seriously as a cinematic work.I think the introduction of Tobias Menzies' is such a strong point. The man plays one of the most despicable villains I have ever seen on television in Outlander. Just channeling a fraction of the hate in that character is enough for you to get invested in the hate for his character. Some of the other characters kind of fade away and feel incomplete but there's enough fun going on to allow you to forgive some of the film's shortcomings.I think with Blood Wars we get the film series' most satisfying sequel despite being flawed. The film is still as stylish as ever and a stronger third act keeps the fuel in the machine. I wouldn't mind if the series ended soon but I think we may have to go through a film or two before the series is at its conclusion. Overall, its nothing special but still better than what I had expected.6.5/10

Review title: Blood Wars does not offer us anything new, even though it is a gratifying return to the origins of the franchise
Review_body:
After four films, the Underworld franchise arrives in its fifth episode. Initially announced as a reboot of the franchise, Underworld: Blood Wars, ended up becoming another continuation of the saga of Selene, the vampire, played by Kate Beckinsale, who had become an outcast of her race. We have here the first feature of the series whose story was not written by Len Wiseman, even though the director remained as producer of the work. The plot begins by revisiting what was previously presented, as usual in the saga. This can be praised as a way to contextualize the scenario for the occasional audience, but I see it as an inability to create a single product or a certificate that they know that the audience itself has no memory of what happened. To make matters worse, part of the plot existing in other films is set aside - at this point even fans can revolt. Who is not a fan of the franchise, the chance to be disappointed and find everything very confusing and repetitive, is huge. Repetitive, by the way, is the word of the day. It is almost always the same and now it is no different.Years have passed since Selene (Kate Backinsale) discovered she had a daughter with Michael Corvin. Away from all those she loves, she remains in her search for her beloved and ends up becoming the target of the lycans, who now have a new leader, Marius (Tobias Menzies). This, however, is only the first of its problems, since the vampire Semira (Lara Pulver) has other plans, involving the protagonist's blood. Fortunately, Selene has some allies, such as David (Theo James), whose first appearance had occurred in The Awakening and his father, Thomas (Charles Dance), one of the oldest immortals still alive.It is true to say that Cory Goodman's script seems more like a succession of attempts to do something interesting, but that they end up not developing completely. Little of what was shown in "The Awakening" is relevant here, with the war between the two races returning to the stage and humans barely being mentioned. The franchise did not talk about magic, putting the origins of vampires and werewolves in a pseudoscience, something abandoned by the new feature that not only presents spells and magic as a concept of afterlife without foot or head, throwing in the trash the (already little) series coherence. The actions taken by some characters are of unspeakable stupidity and the conclusion of the villainous Semira's plan brings laughter from the audience, destroying all the effort that actress Lara Pulver makes to give some credibility to the character. It is also sad to see Kate Beckinsale suffering to give Selene some weight, in view of her daughter's removal, but she is sabotaged by a script that makes the protagonist make decisions that contradict everything we have seen so far. Theo James fails to pass the minimum of conflict in his appearances, even after an important revelation about his past and Charles Dance finds himself criminally wasted on the scene.
However, now under the direction of Anna Foerster, the first woman to direct a film in the franchise, which also marks its debut on the big screen, the franchise gains one more point for bringing female characters of greater prominence. Evidently, the protagonist had always been a woman, but, besides her, all the other relevant characters were men, since even the elderly Amelia had not lasted more than five minutes on screen in the first film. This factor ends up offering new airs for the saga, differentiating the work from what came before considerably. The plot puts three or four female characters in an agency position on the plot: centrally the vampire Selene (Beckinsale), who all hunt, and the villain Semira (Lara Pulver), who conspires and manipulates, in addition to two other vampires (whose role you don't want to deliver here). They are the ones who set in motion and decide history, in a series that in addition always dealt with progressive themes such as pacifism and miscegenation.While the script falls into sameness, what saves the work is the acting work of the entire main cast. With interesting names, the franchise continues to attract us by its portrayal of vampires and werewolves, who, naturally, dialogue with the social classes of our world - one side representing the aristocracy and the other the one subjugated by it. What harms this portrait is the clear rush of the script, which accelerates many developments in an exaggerated way. Many sequences sound like snippets of trailers, exhibiting only a few key points, which hinder the organic progression of the narrative. That said, another problem with Underworld is the way the protagonist's evolution is carried out. From one hour to the next she undergoes a metamorphosis that ends up sounding like a classic example of God ex machina, guaranteeing her what is necessary to overcome the threat in question.The interesting script by Cory Goodman and Kyle Ward manages to add new mythologies to the worn out plot and give an air of freshness to Selene's journey, opening doors to new sequences and ending with praise the loose ends left by the last films, bringing a greater focus about vampire society, which had been portrayed as in ruins since Viktor's death. Here the council returns and, with it, we have a deeper view of how this world works. Unfortunately, this ends up in opposition to what we saw in the previous film - humans are practically forgotten, as if the extermination of the creatures of the night had never existed. Yes, there are mentions that vampires are on the verge of extinction, but the human race is never blamed, no matter how much it was controlled by werewolves in The Awakening. Unfortunately, the old lycan war with vampires is already showing great wear and tear. What we see here is practically the same as what we saw in the first feature and the one before Blood Wars, with subtle differences that, in fact, do not change our view of the narrative as a whole. The necessary renovation of the main narrative line never happens, only in the final minutes, which can mean a sequence that, at last, renews the franchise once and for all, but that is only a hope.
There are moments when the visual of Underworld: Blood Wars surprises, perhaps because Kate Beckinsale herself is as beautiful as she was in the previous films in her leather outfit, just a delusion. The locations are interesting, though few. Some visual choices turn out to be poor and tacky (see the pacifist vampire clan), struggles are lacking in imagination, digital creatures are miserable and the atrocious 3D mixed with the dark tones of the photo make the film almost physically painful to watch, but all of this pales in the face of the dark assembly of production. Foerster and editor Peter Amundson (believe me, a skilled professional with great films like "Circle of Fire" and "Hellboy") managed to make mistakes even in conducting a plan / counterpoint in dialogues, inexplicably pricking a simple conversation between two characters. The photograph continues with the same bluish palette. This is consistent with the visual identity that has been established. The question that remains is: who thought that choice was in good taste? The supposedly Gothic air is pushed down the throat, this being - the pseudo somber tone - the crutch used.The director, Anna Foerster, is a TV veteran, with her work on the TV series "Outlander" as her main CV, but she is completely lost in her big screen debut. The director also shows that she has no idea how to command action sequences, which was for the most important point of a film like this. Foerster misses on the same point that is becoming common in North American action cinema: excessive cuts and camera axes that end up making it impossible for the viewer to understand what is happening. You cannot understand the blows given by the characters, because when the blow happens, there is a cut on top. This ends up taking the impact of the blow and the viewer cannot understand the choreography of the scene, and we do not understand the spatial relationship of the characters.Underworld had everything to become a great franchise in cinema, which in a way happened due to the regularity that the series demonstrated and how it manages to draw audiences, but the quality ended up falling too much, even earning high production is always treated like a film low budget, resulting in scenes that are not convincing and we see many of these scenes in Wars of Blood. The battle of Vampires, Lycans and the races themselves should be explored in a more intelligent way, and now what lies ahead is totally uncertain. It is a fact that Wars of Blood has everything to generate new profits and keep the franchise standing, but it is also very evident that a more serious and cohesive arc is necessary for the continuations to be relevant.In the end, Underworld: Blood Wars does not offer us anything new, even though it is a gratifying return to the origins of the franchise. With points that sound lost in the script and a narrative progression too fast, the work ends up qualifying as a simple action movie, made just for fun, but without delivering anything deeper than that. Still, it is a work that will surely please fans of the franchise and lovers of vampires or werewolves will find a good refuge from the terrible productions that we usually see in cinema today. Underworld, however, needs a makeover - something that differentiates old films from new ones, so that, finally, the Selene saga moves forward. Selene's story is not finished, but that also does not mean that it should be continued, after all what the viewer expects when entering the Angels of the Night is a lot of stylized action and not understanding the protagonist's personal relationships.

Review title: A further extension of the Underworld franchise
Review_body: The culmination of the Underworld series so far feels like just another episode and though there is really nothing new despite the insistence that there is by the characters, it is still an enjoyable ride for loyal fans. I happen to have a strong affection for R-rated genre action films so I'm willing to except some major flaws and still have a decent time at the theaters. One aspect of the Underworld films that has increased through the series is the length as each film feels shorter though I don't know the actual run time for each movie. This film felt extra short.Selene (Kate Beckinsale) returns as a renegade chased by both vampires and lycans. With the help of David (Theo James), Selene escapes from the wolves that hunt her. The lycans rallied from the events of the previous films with a new leader, Marius (Tobias Menzies). Menzies has been fun to watch lately especially in his role in Outlander as Black Jack Randall. He's got the vicious villain look down and brings that to this short film.Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

I must preface this review by noting that I have had no prior connection to the 'Underworld' series. I went in without having seen any of them. My girlfriend wanted to go see it and said it would hopefully be a good bad. In the long run she was right It's bad and I mean really bad. Fortunately it's bad in the best kind of bad. The film has a hilarious streak and not in a 'Batman v. Superman' way. It's always sort of hard to decipher good/bad from bad/bad. The one thing that 'Underworld Blood Wars' has going for it is that it's cast commits to the material with stone cold sincerity. I laughed a lot mainly because a lot of the film is actors desperately trying to elevate garbage material. The main thing with 'Underworld Blood Wars' is that so much of it has been about building the world and leaving bread crumbs for countless future sequels. When our vampires are not fighting they are bickering about bureaucracy and prophecies. I usually hate that kind of stuff but here it is so haphazardly added in that the bad screen writing is almost overwhelmingly blunt. The fact that our cast treats it like it's Shakespeare really does sell it enough to have a chuckle.The juxtaposition between these scenes of vampire bureaucrats and the action might be what make the film work. The action sequences are clichéd too right down to the ending when Selene returns with white streaks in her hair to show she really means business. It's funny. I admire the commitment of the actors but sometimes it's just fun to snicker at a ham.I was not bored by 'Underworld' at all. It's bad but it's too well oiled a cliché to fume over.

The fifth and hopefully last entry in the Underworld franchise. Underworld: Blood Wars was released in (2016) and is probably the most generic and forgettable action movie in the entire franchise. The previous entry Underworld: Awakening (2012) was an attempt to revive the franchise adding new characters and a new storyline that took place in a more modern day setting. Awakening failed to add anything of interest or worth to a storyline that should have ended with Underworld Evolution (2006). Instead of rebooting the franchise or doing something "you know" different the writers and producers of Underworld just keep adding more and more lazy plot devices to a story that ended over ten years ago just to make money.The story this time around follows Selene (Kate Beckinsale) shortly after the events of the last movie. Selenes daughter Eve has since abandoned her and made her promise never to come looking for her so neither Vampires or Lycan can hunt her down and take her blood. Selene remains an outcast to her kind. She now roams the city still looking for Michael but never finding him. The war between Vampires and Lycan continues to rage as the last of the vampire covens reaches out to Selene through David (Theo James) the young vampire she brought back from the dead in last movie and his father Thomas (Charles Dance). The covens council made up of the last of the oldest vampires enlists the help of Selene to train a new generation of Death Dealers so the coven can survive an attack by a new Lycan clan led by a new powerful Lycan named Marius (Tobias Menzies) who is also hunting for Selenes daughter Eve. Selene along with the help of David uncover a traitorous plot devised by council member Semira (Lara Pulver) to steal Selenes powerful blood so she can rule over the last of the vampires without the council.The previous entry took place in a world where humankind knew of the existence of vampires and lycan and were at war with both species. Humankind hunted both species down almost to point of extinction with both vampires and lycan barely surviving. In Blood Wars however humankind have just simply forgotten about those pesky vampire and Lycan theres not even a footnote explaining what happened nothing. Throughout the entire movie the only time you see humans is during overhead shots of the city and when Selene and David take a train journey that's literally it.This is undoubtedly one of the most boring and generic vampire/werewolf action movies I have ever seen. The action what little there is of it is just vampires and werewolves shooting each other with guns GUNS! for god sake when they have fangs and claws and the Lycan can even turn into savage werewolf creatures but instead they just shoot each other and use riot shields. The first two Underworld movies were filled with so much blood and gore that it was awsome to watch for action alone. The Lycan only transform a few times throughout the movie and the transformations look awful and CGI heavy with no blood or body transformation effects like in the first two movies.Kate Beckinsale and Charles Dance are the only ones in the entire movie with any real acting talent. The cast are so bland and generic looking that you could put them in any teenage action movie like The Hunger Games or The Divergent series and they would fit right in.Don't waste your time and money watching this movie it's arguably the worst movie in the entire franchise and hopefully it will be the final entry before they do something even more ridiculous like Underworld in space.

Review title: At Worst; Still Better Than Awakening
Review_body: I am overall very torn on how I feel about Blood Wars. There are a lot of aspects of this movie that I simultaneously quite liked as well as really didn't like, all in the same breath. I have always clocked into Underworld movies for the lore and continuity between them. When that lore or continuity is thrown out the window, it leaves a bad taste in the mouth, which puts Blood Wars in an interesting position. We open up with both Michael and Eve missing, and Selene given up looking for either of them. The whole plot of Awakening where humans are aware of Vampires and Lycans, and have brought them both to the brink of extinction isn't even touched upon at all. On one hand I liked this because Scott Speedman was always terrible, Eve's hybrid make-up was terrible, and the way the Awakening plot was handed was terrible. Blood Wars goes out of its way to actively negate Awakening and carry on as if it never happened, beyond a few minor references here and there. But is breaking the continuity of a bad movie a good excuse to break continuity? Awakening leaves us with a nice cliffhanger to get picked up, and it never is, making the ending of that movie all the more frustrating. Can you imagine if Evolution decided to just not resolve the cliffhanger of Markus reawakening? That's exactly what Blood Wars does. It's even more of an insult when Michael's fate is revealed late into the third act, off-screen. At least Awakening tried to actually show Michael, regardless of how short and unsatisfactorily it was dealt with.So free of the burden of Awakening, Blood Wars shifts to a completely different direction, in an attempt to bring it all back to the struggle between Vampires and Lycans in the first three movies. We even get some power struggles between the Vampire elites, making this the most Underworld-feeling movie since the first, at least on paper. They make an attempt with visuals too, by going back to that Eastern European feeling and Gothic architecture. Even better is we actually expand on that with some Nordic influences, giving the film a chance to expand on the Underworld lore beyond the Corvinus legend. Plot twists and background revelations are back, but how these are presented is...questionable at best. We learn that a relatively new character to the franchise is related to a Vampire elder, which is cool, plays into the power struggle, but also comes completely out of nowhere, and the explanation leaves a lot to be desired (as in, they barely explain it at all).There's also a new Lycan on the scene, who's stronger than the rest, forming his own army to take on the Eastern coven. He just needs the blood of Eve to have a chance of getting through their defences. So who is he? Why is he so strong? The first question is never answered. He's just some random Lycan who's come into power for some unknown reason. The source of his power is explained to a point, in a shocking, albeit downright lazy revelation. So how do they display his power above other Lycans? With a whole new CG model...with a human face. He just looks like an over-large, super muscular and hairy human. Like the worst, cheesiest combination of human and hybrid. It reminded me of the creature in the Thing remake/prequel, or the Scorpion King in The Mummy Returns. Anyway, eventually, with Eve nowhere to be found, the army of Lycans decide to just storm the Vampire fortress anyway, and almost win thanks to blowing out the windows. Why does a Vampire mansion have windows? No idea, but after the initial Vampire melting, it doesn't seem to matter much anyway, because the Nordic vampires come along with their anti-UV skin (I assume anyway).All right, plot and continuity is not this movie's strong point. In truth, it hasn't been a strong point of the franchise in a very long time, so these discrepancies really didn't bother me as much as they should. Likewise continuing to ignore the industrial sonic identity of the first two movies in favour of a generic orchestral score didn't bother me nearly as much as it did in Awakening, because I was prepared for that. But the action is still fairly strong. It can be a little hard to follow at times, but nowhere near as bad as it was in Rise of the Lycans, probably because the increased range of the weaponry allowed the camera to pull back a bit (I don't know, I'm just making excuses here). While being the lowest rated movie since the first, the gore is still on point, with Lycans getting slashed in half, spinal chords getting ripped out, and copious amount of bloodletting.The Nordic Vampires were a nice touch and expansion on the lore as well. Initially they seem to come out of nowhere, but there were three elders each with their own covens, but until now we hadn't seen the other two. The Eastern coven (presumably ruled over by Amelia?) is a familiar sight not too dissimilar to Viktors, but the Nordic coven is a breath of fresh air to the black and blue world. The cold and their affinity with death and the other side gives them an otherworldly appearance that pits them closer to fantasy elves. More crucially, they're the basis for Selene getting more superpowers. This is another point I both liked and disliked at the same time. On one hand her new powers are cool, turning her more ethereal and ghostlike, bringing her closer to death than ever before. Her teleportation looks really cool, and plays out quite well for the climatic battle (as underused as it was). But on the other hand, did she really need even more powers? She was already one of the most powerful creatures in existence. The villain stealing her blood, which apparently transfers her abilities to those who consume it, brings them both to an even level (I guess? If resisting sunlight is a superpower now?). But we can't have Selene evenly matched with her antagonist, she has to be above and beyond more powerful, of course, so lets make her super ghostly and give her teleportation! Honestly, I wouldn't be at all surprised if sparkling in the sunlight was her new power in the next movie. Those frosted-tips look simply glamorous though.Acting wise...well Underworld's never been strong with the acting talent, and Blood Wars is no exception. Beckinsale carries the movie as well as she ever has done, at least getting a bit more chance to actually emote this time around. Charles Dance gets way more screentime, but he gets shafted with terrible, expository dialogue almost throughout. Theo James is adequate. Tobias Menzies does do a good Michael Sheen impression. Lara Pulver laps up all the grotesque cheese her villainess requires. But Daisy Head was little more than some googly eyes, and Bradley James had one of the most inconsistent characters to play with.I've had a fair amount of bad things to say about Blood Wars. It tries its very best to feel like the Underworld of old, with Gothic architecture, a focus back on Selene in an unspecified present day, expands the lore, offers plenty of third act revelations. And yet it probably feels the most detached movie of the franchise. Dropping two of the franchise's main characters for no plot-driven reason is its biggest sin, turning it into the Selene show, and none of its many new characters seem to hold all that much relevance to the older movies at all, while simultaneously being told that they absolutely do. They do guys, really, they're relevant, they're connected by centuries just like all the others, despite never once being mentioned or alluded to in previous movies. The action is serviceable, the visuals are serviceable. I mean at absolute worst Blood Wars is still a much more enjoyable movie, and more respectful to the lore, than Awakening ever was. Ultimately though, this isn't my Underworld. This is a knock-off Underworld. A facsimile. I give Blood Wars a strictly average 5/10. Could've been much better, could've been way worse. I still think I'll just stick with the first two movies from now on.

Review title: At least Kate still looks mighty fine
Review_body:
Underworld: Blood warsLike the Resident Evil franchise the Underworld movies have slowly gotten worse with each instalment.
This latest offering is yet another unimaginative bore.
The only redeeming quality of this franchise is that Kate Beckinsale still looks mighty fine in her costume.
Other than that I lost all interest in this movie within minutes.
As far as story and plot goes it's the same tedious drivel that we have had to endure through in the previous movies.
To be honest I can't even recall what all this nonsense was about because it was just downright boring.
Performances by all are pantomime worthy. It's not even a movie worth using as background noise whilst you cook or wash the dishes.CGI is laughable and although this movie may transfer on to Blu-ray effectively, the higher resolution does the dire special effects no favours.
It's a dark and depressing movie too. Colours rarely pop. A film that may benefit from 4K HDR but to be honest I couldn't be bothered to sit through this snooze fest again to see if HDR makes any difference.Sound is good for the most part but ultimately it is uninspired.
Sure it booms where needed and blades splatter blood with crystal definition but it is nothing that we haven't heard before.
That's the problem with this franchise. It's run its course. Like the Resident Evil movies, each new instalment is just a rehash of what has gone before.
They are films that are made cheaply so they recoup their budget.
None of the film making processes are of a high standard. It's fast food but in movie form.
The trouble is apart from Kate Beckinsale none of this is tasty.

I think it is fairly safe to say that if you did not like any of the other installments in the Underworld movie series then you will not like this one.As usual with these kind of movies it is one where you preferably switch of most higher brain functions before watching and just sit down and enjoy the show. The movie is certainly not a masterpiece when it comes to story and script. Actually the script is, at times, fairly crappy. There are for example a sequence were the Lycans are attacking the stronghold castle of the Vampires and the script writer taught it was a good idea to just let them drive straight into the center of the castle and breach the door before they got challenged. What the f?On the whole the script is a typical Hollywood B-movie concoction that holds little merit. If this would have been the first movie in the series I think there would never had been a series made at all.So why did I like it then? Well, even if the script is nothing to write home about it is not a total disaster and it serves as an excuse to provide 90 minutes of good entertaining Vampire vs Lycan action. Plain and simple.Of course Kate Beckinsale is a good reason for liking the movie as well. Her moving around in her intimidating (and good looking) skintight clothes slashing up Lycans in various creative ways makes up for some of the not so stellar script. I probably pi$$ed of a bunch of feminists there but it is not really like a care about that.The action and the CGI is reasonably well done and another reason to like the movie. Actually, come to think about it, Kate Beckinsale, the action and the CGI is pretty much the reasons I liked this movie.They could have selected a more charismatic bad guy though. For most of the movie I felt Marcus was bland and even a bit dull.It is not the best movie in the series but it does not exactly shame the series either. For me, I have to rate my enjoyment of it as above average compared to movies in general.

Review title: A short review of "Underworld: Blood Wars" (2016)
Review_body: I'm not sure what to say about "Underworld: Blood Wars" (2016). It really differs little from the previous "Underworld" movies. If you've seen those, you've kinda seen this one.The vampires look like underwear models, or maybe a goths-only high school drama club. The werewolves look  not homeless, exactly, but like burly, long-haired, unemployed grunge rockers. Both groups speak portentously and repeatedly about things like "LINEAGE" and "BLOOD LINES" and "THE WAR" and "AMELIA." (Who was Amelia again?) There are the requisite betrayals and forbidden inter-species romances. The entire thing felt like a feature-length music video.Maybe I'm being too harsh. I would actually give this film a 5 out of 10 for at least bringing some good things to the table. Kate Beckinsale is a good actress, and she brings the same magnetism that she always does to Selene, the franchise's protagonist. Charles Dance is always superb, and is always fun to watch. (There are at least two "Game of Thrones" alumni here — one is Dance as a vampire elder, and the other is Tobias Menzies as the leader of the "Lycans.") The nicest surprise, though, was seeing Lara Pulver as an ambitious vampire alpha female — fans of "Sherlock" (2010 – 2017) will recognize her as that series' incarnation of Irene Adler. She's a great actress, and she seems to relish this kind of role.All in all, though, I can't say I actually recommend this.

This review of Underworld: Blood Wars is spoiler free ** (2/5) When a new part of an ongoing series hits the big-screen we all expect it to hit a new part hopefully get over the previous films, this doesn't happen with Underworld: Blood Wars in a hope to bring new fans to the series it does the same thing as it's always done for the past four installments that is bring the same generic action with the same bland story filled with the same hobo-esque Lycan clan trying to kill Selene but she always seems to find a way to survive and it seems that Blood Wars' open-ended denouement may suggest that a sixth film is inevitable.Set a short while after the capture of Selene's (Kate Beckinsale) daughter Eve in Underworld: Awakening they captured her for a blood harvest so the vampires can then turn into a more defined form, a vampire corvinus hybrid which essentially means that they are immune to the sun. We open with Selene narrating her story about her betrayal then we shift to her in a gun fight with some of the Lycan clan, she is then joined by David (Theo James) who is her only ally and confidant at this point as she relies on his help when things go bad. She finds out that the Lycan clan have a new leader, Marius (Tobias Menzies) who is forming a new army of reformed werewolves, so she must go back to her coven and train for one last fight. But it soon transpires that this is just a ruse for Semira (Lara Pulver) the new leader of the coven to form a plan for her betrayal after she killed their last leader Viktor, at this point she is almost dying after an intake of nightshade which in lethal doses can be very painful for her. After she is betrayed she must run to find another coven in the north, where she will train and plan her fight with the Lycans and her fellow Vampires who now are hunting her down for capture and if possible death.The story is joined on with the other films in the series with the help of the same generic fight scenes of Selene shooting down or beating her enemies black and blue, which seems to be quite the challenge for first time director Anna Foerster who not only keeps the fights generic but also steers away from the horror aesthetic of the series, so it now feels like an action film with no horror feel whatsoever. While the others in the series were generic, too, they still had some scares to keep the story going. In addition, it seems that this sequel is adding another tired – seemingly futile attempt to add new fans. There is even less of a story this time it seems that Foerster wanted to rush and just use a lot of action to try to improve the series even the addition flashbacks showing the lives of Marius and the life of David and his father Thomas (Charles Dance), can't quite tackle the overbearing sense of clichés that have grown tired over the last decade.While Beckinsale is constantly dragged into the film's bullsh*t revenge plot, it's not all bad as there are a couple of notable differences; firstly, in the opening of the second act we are taken to a Nordic coven surrounded by beautiful snow-covered mountains with the inhabitants of the coven wearing soft white furs, secondly there is a scene in which Marius and Selene have a showdown on ice both of which thankfully manage to take us away from the familiar territory of a black and blue colour palette. Even though there are a couple of differences to take us away from the generics of the previous there is still a huge amount of clichés, a lot of action and the same bland story that we had in the previous installments, it seems that there is no more hope left for the Underworld series.VERDICT: Like its heroine Blood Wars has run out of ideas and is riddled with tired old clichés that were exciting thirteen years ago but now are old and have lost their touch in this bloody mess which manages to escape the tropes of the previous movies.4/10 the worst in the series

Review title: My least favorite of the movie franchise. Too much David. I didn't care about him or his history. Spiritual mumbo jumbo made up here. Selene is still great.
Review_body: This appears to take place far into the future. In the first couple of movies, Selene is 600 years old, here she describes herself as being 1000 years old. So whatever happened with the war with humans is kind of forgotten about. I'm guessing because the previous movie wasn't liked very well. But it's kind of confusing because of the the tiny flash of her daughter has her looking really young.Too much David, Selene's fanboy. I don't care about him. I don't care about his history. Not enough Selene. But I loved her every moment they had her onscreen. The spiritual stuff was kind of stupid. They just all of a sudden make it up here.Selene being tired of "the life", or leaving her daughter didn't seem to ring true. This is badassed Selene we're talking about here. No way!. She can take care of her kid, especially since said-kid can take of herself.Semira was one-dimensional. Marius was a punk. Varga was a wimp. See how impressed I was with these new characters.The movie didn't have a cheap look like the last movie, so that was good. Had some nice building structures and scenery.I hope if they make more movies they don't decide to make David the star of it. I'd have to stop watching then. As it is, they killed Michael off in this movie as we find out what happened to him. I feel like that act sums up this movie and the state of the franchise. Selene was still great in the action scenes and I still enjoyed her journey, tho not crazy about the whole elder peace guru stuff.I think they should have went with something else in Selene's past history in order to create the plot for the fifth movie. I think the big issue seems to be that the writers didn't know what in hell to do with the kid. Even if she was grown-up now, it sort of stuck Selene in a corner they didn't know how to get out of, so basically they sent the kid away, yet the plot is all about her.I didn't hate it, but I didn't love it. However I still love Selene. I still think she's an awesome female character. And I love watching her action scenes. 6/10

Five years since the events of the last movie underworld awakening, Selene is a hunted fugitive by both the Lycans aka werewolves and the death dealers aka the vampires. Selene daughter eve has been placed into hiding for her own protection knowing that both enemies want her daughter blood to create more hybrids. Selene is once again paired with her ally David and his father David who speak to the vampire clan to allow her clemency for her past crimes. However Selene faces new threats including the new Lycan leader Marius and vampire Samira who wants Selene blood to make herself more powerful. I would say that what makes the film great is the fast pace and action, however I wish it had a longer running time than just 91 minutes, I also wish Michael would have had a more active role in the story.

Review title: It's about time Kate Beckinsale forsakes her leather catsuit
Review_body: This was never a franchise that made any sense or movies of substance or quality. But, it was an interesting take on the vampires & werewolves theme. And Kate Beckinsale looked _very_ good in her leather catsuit.But, it's getting old. All of it. The "interesting take" is washed up and the new things are not very interesting. Yes, our main character looks very good for her age, but, let's face it, she's supposed to be the vampire who doesn't age... it just doesn't work.It's hard to see what would be the next one. Without our main character, it wouldn't make much sense, yet it's hard to see how Kate Beckinsale could work one more time or how replacing her with some other actress would work. Of course, one can always go crazy, have some virus attack vampires and make them age, but... it's about time modern franchises learned when to say enough. "Underworld" can start, then it can teach "Fast & Furious" and hopefully others will pick it up.

Review title: There is no beginning, there is no end, there is only the coming
Review_body: I still remember seeing the first Underworld in the theatre and enjoying it very much, though I didn't see any of the subsequent films at the cinema, only on DVD. I re-watched them in preparation for seeing this film and, as it stands, the original's still the best, with Evolution and Rise of the Lycans vying for second and third place, alternating between the two depending on my mood, while Awakening remains my least favourite. I'm afraid Blood Wars isn't much better. Whilst the fourth film felt like it was just non-stop gory action with little to no story, this film seems to have the opposite problem. Gorehounds needn't fear, there's still some quality violence (most of which the Lycans seem to wind up on the receiving end of, like being split in half and having their spines ripped out). The main problem is the vampire politics are brought to the forefront. The other problem? Super sexy latex-clad vampire Death Dealer, Selene, feels as though she's no longer the focus of her own franchise (though at least she gets some memorable lines/moments). Let's be honest, most people come to see Kate Beckinsale rocking the black latex catsuit like nobody else can. So it remains a mystery as to why the writers appear to be slowly phasing out her character. Please note filmmakers: These films wouldn't be worth continuing without Ms. Beckinsale. Some tend to dismiss her acting ability, but she's what's held this franchise together. So it's disappointing her character is absent for what feels like long stretches. Blood Wars begins like Awakening did, with Kate's/Selene's voice-over (now with added echoing repeating what she's already said!) and clips from the previous films...though, really, if you haven't seen the others, why're you even here? Theo James's David character from Awakening has a much more expanded role this time (now fully replacing Scott Speedman's Michael as the franchise's male lead. Yes, Michael's dead. Barring some future "We only SAID he was dead/were only pretending!" reveal pulled out of the writers' arses, the Smurf is no more). Whether you're a fan of David or not will likely contribute to your enjoyment of the film, as he seems to take over the movie from Selene for significant portions.I'll miss the Selene/Michael relationship, but am not opposed to David's character helping Selene, though it might rub some the wrong way how his backstory/ancestry's delved into so deeply it almost feels like *he's* the film's main star. Those who paid attention to the first films will appreciate references to a certain character who had minimal screen time, yet plays an important part in this film's storyline, while everyone else will be left wondering, "Who?". The blood of Selene and her daughter, Eve (who's referenced aplenty but only appears in the film's closing seconds), also proves important, as there's much exchanging of said blood between different characters. Other than Selene and David, the only significant returning character is Charles Dance's Thomas. Whilst not as memorable as Bill Nighy's Viktor, an actor of his caliber lends some weight/credibility to proceedings. His relationship with his son and heretofore untold connection with a past long-dead character is given prominence. Playing well off Dance is Lara Pulver, sporting constantly changing hairstyles as Semira. They do what they can with the material they're given. Semira's character also provides a cautionary tale in why you shouldn't treat your henchman/lover like crap, as we see play out between her and Bradley James' Varga.Outlander's Tobias Menzies, as Lycan Marius, isn't given anywhere near the complexity of his character from that series, as here he's mainly just another complication in an already rather convoluted story. Nor is his relationship with vampire, Alexia, given much depth...though at least Daisy Head is quite striking, so you don't forget her character. Also memorable on account of their physical appearance are the Nordic Coven, the best of which is Lena (resembling a vampire Daenerys Targaryen). She kicks major arse with a sword and shield (apparently the Nordic Coven *do* bring swords to gun fights), plus also possesses a "teleport" ability of sorts. For a newcomer, Clementine Nicholson fares better with what little she's given compared to others who're given more. She also plays an important part in Selene's physical transformation (including her picking up that handy teleportation ability) to becoming 'more' than she already is...which is just as well, as poor Selene's put through the wringer this time around. It pained me seeing our heroine beaten up/knocked down more than ever, but allowed for a triumphant return, stronger/faster/better than ever...and now with white blonde highlights in her jet black hair.The last couple of films' over-reliance on CGI versus the practical effects for the Lycans of the earlier films is to the movies' detriment, as the CGI creatures just aren't as impressive (and in the case of the Marius man-wolf creature, rather laughable/dredging up bad memories of the Scorpion King from The Mummy Returns...though not quite THAT bad). Note for future movies: Refrain from going half/half, either human or full beast is the way to go. Clearly this isn't intended as the franchise's final film, but assuming another one does indeed happen, that probably *should* be the last. The earlier Underworld films weren't exactly 'high art', but they felt like they had more substance to them than these last two. Given how much time was devoted to Eve previously, it's strange she's mainly absent here (perhaps she'll play a more significant role in the next movie?). I feel the franchise lost something after delving more into the world of men, but at least this one LOOKS more like an Underworld film than Awakening did (though the music/score's sadly lacking Wedard's 'Leidenschaft'). Say what you will about Len Wiseman, but I feel these later films' direction have suffered from his absence. My main hope for the next movie? That the filmmakers remember who this franchise's star is and give Beckinsale/Selene the attention/importance/prominence she deserves.

World of vampires and Lycans is taking us to battle for most precious blood of all, Eve's blood. And what a mess of a movie did Anna Foerster did for her first directorial movie followed by a horrible plot telling. Underworld: Blood Wars (2016) Starring: Kate Beckinsale, Theo James, Lara Pulver, Tobias Menzies, Charles Dance, Bradley James, Daisy Head, Oliver Stark, Eva Larvoire, Alicia Vela-Bailey, India Eisley, Trent Garrett, David Bowles, and Brian Caspe Directed By: Anna Foerster Review PROTECT THE BLOODLINE It's January 2017! You know what that means, more shitty horror movies! But hey this is a guilty pleasure of mine, I love the first three underworld movies, they're great films in my opinion but Awakening was an unnecessary pile of trash. They should have ended it with the prequel Rise of The Lycans. As we once again get a prologue to past events from the other four movies (much like those even worse Resident Evil Movies which doesn't even have one good film under there belt) we find Selene as an outcast being hunted down by a new Lycan leader Marius, who is looking for Selene's daughter which they don't even say her name if she even has one. The film is very short if it weren't for the fact that I liked Selene I would have forgotten I saw this movie. But if you want to just have fun in the movies and you like horror (like I do) then go see it if you so wish. I'm giving Underworld: Blood Wars a two out of five.

Review title: least favorite in the series but still has some great action; even in a lightless room, way too dark
Review_body: I have a strong liking to this series, but this was easily the weakest installment. As if its predecessor wasn't stretched thin as it were, this movie had a basic plot that tried to be innovative by simply rehashing elements from the original, and introducing only one new thing. That said, some of the action is really entertaining, especially with the (re)introduction of swords into fights against lycans. Probably the coolest scene was the one out on the ice with the hybrid villain, partly because it was actually visible. Unfortunately so much of the flick is doused in poor lighting, and with characters who wear all black with black hair and black fur, it's a bit brutal on the eyes more often than not. A shame, too, because some of it would've been even better had I been able to see more of it. Which I imagine is one reason why they frosted Selene's tips, so you could discern her in combat more easily; also just to change it up a bit. Ultimately it offers some closure to the series while still proposing a pickup point. Fans of Beckinsale won't be disappointed; most of the characters were hit and miss for me, but I did love Charles Dance as I always do. While I did give this a generous 7 (more close to a high 6), and I gave its predecessor a 7, too, I definitely enjoyed Underworld Awakening (2012) more.

Now, I'm familiar with the first two films, but I'll be honest, all that I can remember well is Kate Beckinsale in tightly cladded, black leather, looking like a hotter CatWoman, but in fact, she's a blood sucking bat woman. I didn't even know there was another two films! Rise of Lycans that was without Beckinsale (that might have something to do with it) and Awakening which did have Beckinsale. TV director and cinematographer, Anna Foerster makes this her big screen debut, but it's not a good start. It's not horrendous and is properly a good opportunity out of a bad situation, however this unfortunately puts doubts in my mind about her Source Code 2 that's in currently in development. I'm not sure what I missed but there appears to be a lot of back stabbing, characters defecting or returning for redemption. For someone who has skipped the previous two, it didn't really make much sense with the flashbacks but it's not really hard to figure out and follow. It's unfortunately a messy and poorly scripted story, drowning in borrowed elements from other films, making it awfully predictable where it tries to be clever. One scene in particular immediately reminded me the battle at Helm's Deep in LotRs Two Towers. It's very rushed and it progresses faster than their superhuman healing powers. One minute they're on a train, then they're riding horses across a snow plain to all of sudden scaling a cliffside. Just seemed utterly pointless and stupid. There are characters and story elements that get introduced but are quickly pushed to one side to make way for more plot lines or twists, the side characters especially are not developed enough. Beckinsale fits into her right leather comfortably but she isn't in the film as much as I was expecting, giving some of the story to Theo James' David. Again, because of this rushed though balanced storyline, you never feel like you're getting the full picture and being a fan of James, I believe he's capable of giving so much more. I want to see how he does on the frontline, they should give him a superhero tryout. The action was as expected, decent enough to be entertaining but the bullet dodging makes it borderline spoof; and what's with all the grunting during the dramatic stand off scenes!? David grunts cuts to Marius grunting back, David grunts some more, Marius I think sighs and grunts at the same time, only more intense. This goes on for what feels like a good thirty seconds! I didn't feel anything with the bad guys, in fact, I felt little for any of the characters. Marius, played by Tobias Menzies, wasn't really bad enough, don't know what to make of him. And Lara Pulver's Semira just appeared to be a cheap version of most of Eva Green's nasties. I can't speak for the previous sequels but the first film boasted a decent soundtrack with tracks from Bowie, A Perfect Circle and Amy Lee from Evanescence, something that's the expected from this sub-genre of movies. Michael Wandmacher composes a fitting score but nothing memorable, and all sounds very much the same throughout. It appears I don't have anything good to say about this movie, however, if I was of a younger generation of movie-goer, I might enjoy this as a brainless action fantasy flick. But I ended up laughing at a lot of it, especially the bullet dodging. It's not worthy of the big ticket price and it really doesn't urge me to watch the rest of franchise. Review title: Autistic Reviewers Opinion Of This Movie.
Review_body: The fifth installment of the franchise...was it worth the wait,and is it better than the previous installments? Read to find out! Selene has lost her daughter and has no idea on where to find her. A Lycan by the name of Marius (played by Tobias Menzies) is after Selene's daughter and threatens all the Vampire council. They are now under attack by Marius and his army, and Selene is the only one who can end end this! Kate Beckinsale returns and she is still doing great! The main problem with this film is that there so many plot holes and so unexplained things (which we wont go into), and the movie had so many slow points. Some scenes were pointless and could been left out. But once the film gets going and picks up the pace it really does have something great to offer. The fight/shooting scenes are excellent to say the the least! Wonderfully edited. The problem is by the end it doesn't really leave you wanting more. It just leaves you with a feeling of "Oh, that's it?" All in all seriousness it's Kate Beckinsale that holds this franchise of Underworld together. It's possibly the weakest one in the series, but it's not a catastrophe, and it does have lots of good scenes. Definitely for die hard fans of the series and not sure for anyone who isn't of the Underworld series. The Autistic Reviewers give this 6/10 (2.5/5 stars).

Review title: This continues the story but on a meandering path
Review_body: There is not a strong story here and there are questions not well answered (such as, "What kind of creature is the antagonist?, "What is this otherworldly spiritual insight thing?", and "Why does she not explode from perspiration from wearing that outfit?").Basically, Selene is pursued by everybody, a few threads are connected, and a portion of the audience remains in awe of how Beckinsale can maintain her svelte figure well into her forties. There is also a faint unconvincing sigh about the story continuing.If you are into the whole Underworld series, this is worth watching. Otherwise, this is just a movie. (What makes me wonder is how they could have turned this into five films while Van Helsing only had one go at ti.)

I liked this movie way better then the last one. A lot of action and a good twist to the story involving the vampires. The main issue I had (this part is a spoiler so don't read it if you haven't seen it) is the Killing off of the Michael character. The last movie led up to his return so it was a real let down and not believable the way he died. This was badly written and a lazy & disrespectful way to remove a lead character. Holding him captive by Marius or not including him at all in this chapter would have been better. He needed to be part of this entire series. I like Kate obviously but she can't carry the whole movie. There needs to be a strong male protagonist especially with so many of the good original characters gone. It makes no sense not to include him, and the series has suffered with his absence. He needs to be brought back in some aspect for the next final movie, even if its just newly filmed flashback scenes with Eve to finish it off!

Review title: Selena has to battle a group of Lycans led by a powerful leader called Marius in order to defend her race.
Review_body: The Underworld franchise is surprisingly reliable when it comes to entertainment. This installment is no exception. It balances action, and intrigue very well, and keeps you gripped from start to finish. Kate Beckinsale owns the role, and the supporting cast played by Charles Dance as her ally and Tobias Menzies as the main villain. Dance has an enormous screen presence and projects the authority required of his character. Menzies plays a brilliant villain, and is able to show more complexity than other talented actors playing Marvel villains. Menzies' character is definitely fearsome and ruthless, but is also charismatic enough to play a believable Lycan leader. Even we know not much of his back story, his character is not just one screaming villain. Apart from the acting, the action sequences are great, and the climactic battle between Beckinsale's and Menzie's characters are worth the the run time. This is one of the movies that makes vampires alluring, yet menacing (unlike the Twilight franchise which made vampires become emo-teens). In short, if you are a fan of horror action, Underworld: Blood wars should be on your list.

Review title: Only for fans and few other people
Review_body:
The 2017 has marked a great success for several films, "Underworld: Blood Wars" is not among them (film produced in 2016 but distributed in many countries, including the US, in 2017).

In addition, after five films I must say that I have also been keen on the characters and the world around them.
In short, it is the worst, together with the fourth, of "Underworld", a saga that I would almost define my guilty pleasure, but it remains one of them, so always fun, violent and as ugly as beautiful.

I've been a huge fan of the series and I must say this film was just horrible. It had no connection to the original movies whatsoever. This is just another unnecessary sequel with some nice action sequences and awful plot. After being disappointed by Awakening, I had some hope in this one but alas!How and when did the Lycans get so powerful and when did all the Vampires start dying out? No explanation for that. Huge loophole. SPOILER ALERT: They never mentioned anything about Micheal and then eventually in the end it is shown that Micheal was killed. At least show us what happened and how it happened. I just wanna ask the makers: If you guys want us to enjoy these movies then at least come up with a sensible plot or at least tie up the loose ends. I was expecting it in this movie and then all of a sudden he is shown to be dead without any explanation whatsoever.Overall this film is in no way connected to the first 2 movies (which were wonderful).
